results.title: Carolin and the Frog
results.brief_description: Fact meets fantasy in the forests of East Gippsland. Carolin is a city kid; she doesn’t like the bush. Her parents are excited about their holiday in East Gippsland but to Carolin it spells dirt, insects and discomfort…until she encounters a frog! She rushes into the bush to find her voice and discovers the enchantment of the forest. Deals with the flora and fauna of East Gippsland and explores the meaning of wilderness.

results.title: Carnivorous plants
results.brief_description: Shows the unusual structure and behaviour of the Venus Flytrap, Trumpet Plant, Cobra Plant, Pitcher Plant, Sundew Plant and Utricularia, which are all species of carnivorous plants. Suitable for upper primary, lower and middle secondary levels.

results.creator_credit: National Geographic Society, Oxford Scientific Films and Gerald H Thompson
results.brief_description: Features plants which eat animals, including the Venus Fly-trap, the sundew plant, the bladderwort and the pitcher plant. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Carnivore capers
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development, Tony Paice and Mark Laughlin
results.brief_description: This program set in the Royal Melbourne Zoo looks at three types of carnivores - lions, cape hunting dogs and seals, and follows the keeper through a typical day.

results.title: Carnival in Quebec
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Roger Blais and Jean Palardy
results.brief_description: A colorful record of Quebec City’s winter carnival - with all the fun and frolic of a southern Mardi Gras but in gleaming winter setting. Fine examples of snow sculpture, pageants, parades, sporting events, a torch-light parade on skis, folk dancing and fireworks, fill three weeks of festivities and pay due respect to King Winter.

results.title: Carnarvon
results.brief_description: Aboriginals of central Queensland left cave paintings and rock engravings in the caves of the Carnarvon ranges. Today the Aboriginals are gone and the true meanings of the many unique designs may never be known.
results.description: Aboriginals of central Queensland left cave paintings and rock engravings in the caves of the Carnarvon ranges. Today the Aboriginals are gone and the true meanings of the many unique designs may never be known.

results.title: Carnal knowledge
results.brief_description: Jules Feiffer’s bittersweet story follows the diverse paths of Jack Nicholson and Art Garfunkel as each tries to match their sexual fantasies with an uncooperative reality. One chooses the narrow confines of the marriage contract, the other the broader pleasures of playing the field. They meet as roommates at college in the 1940s, where Candice Bergen is the object of mutual attention. We meet them again in the 1950s when Garfunkel is a bored suburban husband, and Nicholson is still playing the field, notably with Ann-Margaret. The final 13 minutes of the film are set in the late 1960s.

results.title: Carmen de Sevilla
results.creator_credit: English Television Drama and William C. Faure
results.brief_description: Based on the opera “Carmen” by Georges Bizet and on the original production by the Performing Arts Council of the Transvaal, the Mercedes Molina Spanish Dance Theatre combine flamenco with traditional ballet to present this theatrical performance for television. Features Mercedes Molina as Carmen and Enrique Segovia as Jose.

results.title: Carmen [DeMille]
results.creator_credit: David Zucker and Cecil B. DeMille
results.brief_description: The story that inspired Bizet’s immortal opera is here dramatically recreated with Metropolitan Opera diva Geraldine Farrar as the eponymous, seductive Carmen. Bizet’s score is performed by the London Philharmonic Orchestra. Cast also includes Wallace Reid, Pedro de Cordoba and Horace B Carpenter.

results.title: Carmen
results.creator_credit: Allied Vision, Classical Productions, Ken Scorfield and Gavin Taylor
results.brief_description: The lavish and spectacular television production of Georges Bizet’s “Carmen”, staged at London’s Earls Court in June 1989, proved beyond doubt the resounding success of opera on such a grand scale. Playing to sell-out audiences of over twelve thousand at each performance, the production drew rave reviews from all the critics. Starring Maria Ewing, who has now made this part her own, “Carmen” was staged in the centre of Earls Court, surrounded on all sides by the audience to create the atmosphere of a Spanish bullring.
